Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Forces in Axonal Elongation
Award.AbstractNarration: Axons are long cellular cables that conduct information through the nervous system. Despite a century of investigation, how axons elongate is poorly understood. This question is important because axonal elongation wires the brain during development and is ultimately responsible for how individuals think and perceive the world. The PI's approach to studying this problem is to monitor the process of axonal elongation in vivo using advanced microscopy in living intact Drosophila (fruitfly) embryos, and in vitro on individual neurons grown on glass coverslips. These classic cell biological approaches will be combined with biophysical analysis and powerful genetic tools developed in Drosophila to answer the following questions: 1) What are the cellular mechanics of elongation in vitro and in vivo? (2) How do forces control axonal assembly? (3) How do guidance cues cause axons to turn? Answering these questions will illuminate the understanding of the genetic and cellular mechanisms of axonal elongation. This project will support the training of graduate and undergraduate students, and has an outreach component that exposes K-12 students, undergraduates, graduate students, and secondary physical science teachers to cell biology, genetics, microscopy, and contemporary questions in neuroscience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two major questions in neurobiology are, “How is the brain wired during development?” and “How can neuronal regeneration be improved following injury or disease?” Answering both requires an understanding of the fundamental process by which axons, the long cables that transmit information in the nervous system, lengthen. The focus of our work in this proposal was determining if axons are ‘dynamic solids’ that lengthen as the result of the addition of new material at the tip or are ‘active fluids’ that lengthen because forces generated in neurons cause them to stretch like piece of ‘silly putty’. At deeper level, our question was whether the development of the brain is primarily explained in terms of polymer chemistry whereby the assembly of proteins into filaments underlies the formation of the axon or in terms of physics whereby forces drive the forward flow of material.

 

Intellectual merit: To investigate, we developed novel approaches for directly visualizing the transport and addition of material in axons inside of living embryos from the fruit fly (i.e. Drosophila Melanogaster). To illustrate, we included a picture of growing neurons as they are making their way from the central nervous system out to the muscles. We found the axons lengthened through the bulk forward flow of material. To determine the relevance of these results to vertebrates, we then compared the outgrowth of Drosophila neurons, with the neurons of higher vertebrates grown on glass coverslips (i.e. in vitro). We found the same pattern of growth in both, which suggests that the basic process of by which axons lengthen is highly conserved been widely differing species. To gain a better standing of the forces that drive bulk flow, we developed novel approaches for measuring sub-cellular force generation and further investigated the role of molecular motors in powering the flow of materials in the axon. Together the key findings of this proposal suggests axonal lengthening is powered by molecular motors that drive the bulk forward advance of materials along the axon in a process that is highly conserved between species.

 

Broader impact: This project generated new and fundamental insights into the process of axonal lengthening which could potentially help explain how the brain is wired in development and could lead to the development of more effective approaches to promoting neuronal regeneration. In addition, it provided training for graduate and undergraduates at the intersection of physics and biology. The findings of this research have been shared with the general public, high school science teachers and undergraduate students through various forums, as well as to other scientists through presentations at conferences and publications in journals.
